content: Establishment of Commission on Crime and Violence. The "National Commission on Crime and Violence in America" is established with 22 members appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, and President pro tempore of the Senate. The National Commission on Crime and Violence in America is established with 22 members appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, and President pro tempore of the Senate. The appointments aim to ensure diversity in racial, ethnic, and gender representation, as well as expertise in sociology, psychology, law, law enforcement, social work, and urban poverty issues. The National Commission on Crime and Violence in America will have 22 members appointed within 60 days of the Act's enactment. Members will serve until the Commission's termination and must meet monthly in Washington, D.C. A quorum of 12 members is required for meetings, and a Chairperson and Vice Chairperson will be designated within 15 days of appointments. The Commission members will appoint a Chairperson and Vice Chairperson. Vacancies must be filled within 30 days. Members receive no pay but can claim travel expenses. SEC. 2. DUTIES. The Commission is tasked with reviewing the effectiveness of criminal justice approaches, examining the impact of changes to laws on crime, studying the effects of immigration laws on crime, addressing youth gang problems, and investigating the role of assault weapons in violence in the United States. The Commission in the United States aims to convene hearings nationwide to gather input from various professionals and citizens, review all aspects of the criminal justice system, develop a comprehensive crime control plan for the 1990s, highlight successful crime prevention programs, and seek ideas from outside the traditional criminal justice community. The Commission aims to recommend improvements in coordination of crime control efforts, study factors contributing to crime and violence, and propose actions to reduce them. It also seeks to allocate correctional resources effectively, considering disproportionate incarceration rates among minority groups. The Commission aims to recommend improvements in coordination of crime control efforts and study factors contributing to crime and violence. It also seeks to address disproportionate incarceration rates among minority groups by considering alternatives to incarceration. The Commission appoints a Director who is paid at the rate of basic pay for level V of the Executive Schedule. The Director can appoint staff with approval and without regard to certain civil service laws. The Director can also procure temporary services with approval. The Director can appoint staff and procure temporary services under section 3109(b) of title 5, United States Code. Federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission. The General Services Administration will provide office space for the Commission's headquarters. The Director has the power to appoint staff and procure temporary services. Federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission. The General Services Administration will provide office space for the Commission's headquarters. SEC. 5. POWERS. The Commission may conduct public hearings, delegate authority to its members or agents, secure information from federal agencies, and accept gifts or property. The Commission may accept gifts, bequests, or devises of services or property to aid its work. Money and proceeds from sales received in this manner will be deposited in the Treasury for disbursement upon the Commission's order. The Commission is also authorized to use the United States mails like other Federal agencies. SEC. 6. REPORTS. The Commission is required to submit monthly activity reports to the President and Congress. Additionally, it must provide an interim report containing findings, recommendations, cost estimates, and a dissemination strategy. A final report with detailed findings and conclusions must be submitted before the Commission's termination. The final report of the Commission includes detailed findings, conclusions, recommendations, cost estimates, and an assessment of implemented recommendations. The President is required to print and make the report available to the public. The Commission will terminate 2 years after designating a Chairperson and Vice Chairperson.
